Introduction

Infectious genital ulcers are sores that appear on the genitalia due to sexually transmitted bacteria or viruses.  Each condition that causes infectious genital ulcers has distinct characteristics and requires specific diagnostic and management strategies.



All share the common risk factors of:



  • Unprotected sexual intercourse
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • History of other sexually transmitted infections (STIs)
  • Immunosuppression


Depending on the underlying cause, infectious ulcers may differ in appearance, associated symptoms, and number of ulcers present (single or multiple).  They can be further divided into painful (eg, herpes simplex virus [HSV], chancroid) and nonpainful (eg, syphilis, lymphogranuloma venereum, granuloma inguinale) lesions.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV)

Pathogenesis



HSV is an enveloped, double-stranded DNA virus with 2 serotypes: HSV-1 and HSV-2.  Classically, HSV-1 is associated with gingivostomatitis (vesicles on the anterior oral mucosa), and HSV-2 is associated with genital infection.  Infection with either serotype can occur at either location.



HSV infects epithelial cells through interactions with surface glycoproteins and replicates within the skin.  It also enters sensory neurons and, through retrograde transport, establishes lifelong latent infection within sensory ganglia.  Therefore, periodic reactivation occurs.

Clinical presentation



HSV classically presents with multiple painful, grouped vesicles with an erythematous base (

image 1
).  The genital HSV lesions erode into ulcers over time.  The initial infection of HSV may be accompanied by systemic symptoms (eg, fever, malaise) and painful lymphadenopathy.  Recurrent outbreaks are typically milder and shorter in duration.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis is often suspected based on the characteristic appearance of the lesions; however, because HSV can mimic other diseases as the lesions change from vesicles to ulcers, diagnosis requires laboratory confirmation.  This is most often accomplished through viral PCR.  Other confirmatory tests include:



  • Viral culture (lower sensitivity, particularly as lesions heal)
  • Tzanck test (shows giant, multinucleated cells)
  • Direct fluorescence antibody testing

Management



HSV is a lifelong infection with periodic recurrence; therefore, management is focused on shortening the duration and severity of symptoms.  This is accomplished through antiviral medications (eg, acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir), which inhibit viral replication and reduce the severity and duration of outbreaks.  Other measures include analgesics and sitz baths to reduce pain.  Patients should also be counseled on the prevention of transmission to other sexual partners through consistent barrier use.

Prognosis



HSV is a lifelong infection that has recurrent episodes and outbreaks.  However, it can be managed effectively with periodic antiviral therapy during outbreaks.  Limiting transmission to others is an important component of lifelong management.

Chancroid

Pathogenesis



Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi, which infects skin through microabrasions that develop from sexual intercourse.  H ducreyi likely uses pili to attach to the extracellular matrix and heat shock protein for epithelial cell adherence.  Secreted cytotoxins lead to epithelial injury with the subsequent formation of a painful ulcer.



On Gram stain, the organisms appear as curved, gram-negative rods, often in a clumping pattern (ie, "school of fish").

Clinical presentation



Chancroid has a 4- to 10-day incubation period; during that time, erythematous papules rapidly erode into painful ulcers with well-demarcated but ragged borders (

image 2
).  Often multiple ulcers appear along the sites where sexual contact occurs (eg, penis in males, vulva and vaginal introitus in females).  The ulcers are soft and deep with erythematous bases covered by yellow or gray exudate.  Chancroid infection drains to inguinal lymph nodes where painful lymphadenitis can develop, often with buboes (ie, lymph node liquefaction) formation.

Diagnosis



A definitive diagnosis is difficult because the organism is fastidious and most laboratories are not equipped for proper testing.  Therefore, a probable diagnosis is made in a patient with a typical presentation if other STIs (eg, HSV, syphilis) have been ruled out.  Definitive testing includes culture (requires specialized media and environment) and nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT).

Management



Management involves antibiotic therapy with azithromycin or ceftriaxone, which is curative.  Inguinal buboes require drainage (eg, aspiration, incision and drainage).

Prognosis



The overall prognosis is good with appropriate antibiotic treatment; however, it is vital to treat sexual partners to prevent reinfection.  Potential complications of long-standing infection may increase the risk for scarring and phimosis in men.

Syphilis

Pathogenesis



Syphilis is an STI caused by the spirochete, Treponema pallidum, which gains access to subcutaneous tissue through microabrasions in the skin.  The initial infection produces an ulcerative lesion known as a chancre.  Although the chancre typically resolves spontaneously within 6 weeks of onset, improper treatment may lead to systemic spread of the infection, followed by secondary and/or late syphilis.



This article focuses on a general review of genital lesions; therefore, primary syphilis is the main topic.  The stages of syphilis (primary, secondary, latent, and tertiary) are reviewed in detail in a separate article.

Clinical presentation



Primary syphilis occurs within 3 weeks of exposure and manifests as a single painless ulcer (chancre (

image 3
)) at the site of inoculation.  The ulcer is typically firm with a clean base and may be associated with painless lymphadenopathy.  Resolution of the ulcer without intervention commonly occurs within 6 weeks.

Diagnosis



The primary mode of diagnosis is through serologic testing, which involves nontreponemal tests (rapid plasma reagin [RPR, venereal disease research laboratory [VDRL]) and treponemal tests (fluorescent treponemal antibody-absorption [FTA-ABS], Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay [TP-PA]) (

).  Nontreponemal tests are nonspecific and evaluate serum reactivity to the cardiolipin-cholesterol-lecithin antigen.  These are quantitative tests with results reported as titers that increase shortly after transmission, remain positive during untreated infections, and slowly decrease following successful treatment.



Treponemal tests evaluate specific antibodies against treponemal antigens.  Treponemal serology is qualitative and reported as either positive or negative.  Following infection, treponemal testing is positive for life.



Darkfield microscopy is rarely used and can be used only for primary lesions.  Spirochetes are too small to be visualized by direct microscopy; they require a special condenser that casts an oblique light.

Management



Management is with antibiotics, primarily with benzathine penicillin G.  In penicillin-allergic patients, doxycycline or azithromycin may be used.  Nontreponemal serologic testing is used for monitoring treatment response.  Treatment of sexual partners is critical for preventing reinfection.

Prognosis



The prognosis is excellent with early treatment.  Lack of treatment of primary syphilis leads to secondary, latent, and tertiary syphilis.  Untreated tertiary syphilis can lead to neurologic (eg, tabes dorsalis, Argyll Robertson pupils) and cardiovascular (eg, aortitis [ie, vasa vasorum destruction], aortic aneurysms) damage.

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV)

Pathogenesis



Chlamydia trachomatis is a small, gram-negative (difficult to stain), obligate, intracellular bacterium.  Serotypes A-C cause ocular infection in children, serotypes D-K cause urogenital (sexually transmitted) infections and inclusion conjunctivitis, and serotypes L1-L3 cause LGV.  Histologically, LGV lesions contain areas of mixed granulomatous and neutrophilic inflammation with intracytoplasmic chlamydial inclusion bodies.

Clinical presentation



The primary stage occurs 3-12 days after exposure and begins with a small, painless genital ulcer containing infected cells.  The secondary stage follows the appearance of the ulcer 2-6 weeks later by swollen, painful, coalescing inguinal nodes (buboes) that can develop stellate abscesses and rupture.  The tertiary stage develops if LGV is left untreated and is characterized by fibrosis, lymphatic obstruction, and anogenital strictures and fistulas.

Diagnosis



A presumptive diagnosis is made in patients with characteristic clinical examination findings and positive C trachomatis NAAT.  Serologic testing is supportive of the diagnosis, but it cannot distinguish active from prior infection.  A definitive diagnosis is made only with LGV-specific molecular PCR tests, which are not widely available.

Management



Management involves antibiotic therapy with doxycycline; erythromycin may be used as an alternate.  Inguinal buboes may require aspiration or drainage.

Prognosis



The prognosis is good with appropriate antibiotic treatment.  Long-standing, untreated infection can lead to complications, including chronic genital ulceration and lymphatic obstruction.

Granuloma inguinale

Pathogenesis



Granuloma inguinale, also known as donovanosis, is an STI caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It initially manifests as a painless genital papule that eventually ulcerates; however, lymphadenopathy is uncommon.  Intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies are diagnostic.  If donovanosis is untreated, scarring and strictures can lead to severe lymphatic obstruction and lymphedema (elephantiasis).

Clinical presentation



Granuloma inguinale manifests as a painless genital papule that eventually ulcerates.  The ulcers are beefy and red and have a characteristic rolled edge of granulation tissue.  Unlike in LGV, lymphadenopathy is uncommon in granuloma inguinale.  However, untreated donovanosis can lead to scarring and strictures with severe lymphatic obstruction and lymphedema (elephantiasis).

Diagnosis



Diagnosis is made with biopsy of the ulcer demonstrating intracytoplasmic Donovan bodies (small, oval, immobile cocci located within macrophages that stain deep purple).  Grain stain and culture can also be used for diagnosis, although the organism is difficult to culture and stain.

Management



Management involves antibiotic therapy with azithromycin.  Doxycycline can be used as an alternative.

Prognosis



The overall prognosis is good with appropriate antibiotic treatment.  If left untreated, potential complications include severe lymphatic obstruction and lymphedema (elephantiasis).

Summary



Infectious genital ulcers are sores that appear on the genitalia due to sexually transmitted bacteria or viruses.  Depending on the underlying cause, infectious ulcers may differ in appearance, associated symptoms, and number of ulcers present (single or multiple).  They can be further divided into painful (eg, herpes simplex virus [HSV], chancroid) and nonpainful (eg, syphilis, lymphogranuloma venereum, granuloma inguinale) lesions (
